item.title: Imprint
item.description: If I type that then what will happen?

item.title: 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3' and Romanticism
Dissertation: Issues of Authorship, Gender, and Selfhood in Charlotte Brontë's 'Jane Eyre' and 'Villette'
item.description: This dissertation was written under the supervsion of Cath Sharrock during my study of the Literature Dissertation Post-1789 module at UEA. Contents Introduction Chapter One: Jane Eyre and the (Re)Clamation of the ‘Self’

item.title: On the Move: Exploring the Agency of the Uncanny in H. G. Wells' 'The Red Room'
item.description: This essay was written during my study of the Ghosts, Haunting and Spectrality module at UEA. [Uncanny] is a term used both to describe and create unease.

item.title: The Haunting of the Derridean Spectre in 'The Signalman' by Charles Dickens
item.description: This essay was written during my study of the Ghosts, Haunting and Spectrality module at UEA. Here is – or rather there is, over there, an unnameable or almost unnameable thing: something, between something and someone, anyone or anything[1]

item.title: Empathy and Literariness in Charles Darwin's 'On the Origin of Species'
item.description: This essay was written during my study of the Victorian Writing module at UEA. Reading ‘The Origin [of Species]’ is an act which involves you in a narrative experience.

item.title: Man Vs. Nature: Romantic Perspectives on Humans and Nature in William Blake's 'Spring' and John Clare's 'Crows in Spring'
item.description: This essay was written during my study of the Romanticism 1780-1840 module at UEA. On thy stupendous summit, rock sublime! […] I would recline, while Fancy should go forth (Charlotte Smith, “Beachy Head,” l.
